Award.AwardTitle: Derived categories of complete intersections and Hochschild cohomology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal concerns the structure of the derived categories and associated triangulated categories arising in commutative algebra, and is partly motivated by developments in the representation theory of finite dimensional algebras, and in the cohomology of finite groups. The research focuses both on qualitative aspects of the derived category (for example, support varieties) and on quantitative aspects (for dimension, in the sense of Rouquier). The Hochschild cohomology algebra emerges as a critical player in these investigations, for it acts on the derived category and to capture significant homological information about it, especially over complete intersection rings.

In studying a topological space (or other geometric objects) it is often useful to consider how it can be built out of simpler objects, like discs or spheres. One can then attach numerical invariants to the building process (for example, how many steps are required?) to obtain a measure of the complexity of the object. Surprisingly, similar considerations turn out to be extremely fruitful also in the more discrete world of algebraic structures. The questions addressed in the proposal seek to investigate algebraic gadgets called commutative rings, which arise naturally in various branches of mathematics and physics, from this perspective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In diverse fields like cryptography, pattern recognition, and theoretical physics, one is often faced with the problem of studying the set of solutions of a given collection of polynomial equations. In the second half of the 19th century, David Hilbert discovered that there was a close relationship between such solution sets and the class of polynomial functions defined on them. It has been extremely profitable to study the solution sets via these class of functions because they carry extra structure: they can be added, or subtracted, and multiplied; in other words, they form a commutative ring. Over the last century, commutative rings have arisen naturally in many other ways (for example, as invariants that one attaches to some mathematical object) in combinatorics, topology, and other branches of mathematics. Consequently, commutative algebra (which is the study of commutative rings) has been enriched, and constantly invigorated, by ideas and problems from these fields.

The main thrust of this project is to study commutative rings using perspectives and techniques developed in algebraic topology, that, loosely speaking, is concerned with study of the shape of spaces via numerical, or more complicated, invariants attached to them. In studying a topological space (or other geometric objects) it is often useful to consider how it can be built out of simpler objects, like discs or spheres. One can then attach numerical invariants to the building process (for example, how many steps are required?) to obtain a measure of the complexity of the object. Surprisingly, similar considerations turn out to be extremely fruitful also in the more discrete world of algebraic structures, and in particular, in commutative algebra. 


In the past few years, the PI and his collaborators - notably, Dave Benson (working on the modular representations of finite groups) and Henning Krause (working on finite dimensional algebras) —  have been exploring these ideas in commutative algebra and related disciplines. They have been developing techniques to detect when objects (in an appropriate context) can be built out of each other, in terms of invariants  motivated by constructions from commutative algebra. Using these they have settled long-standing open problems in the modular representation theory of finite groups, and, more recently, also in the representation theory of finite group schemes.


One of the PI’s graduate students has written a Ph.D. thesis on this topic. In addition, in May 2010, the PI, along with Benson and Krause, ran an week-long seminar at the Mathematical Research Institute, in Oberwolfach, directed at graduate students, post-docs, and early career faculty, drawn from across the mathematical spectrum. Some of the participants of that seminar have now begun to contribute actively to this field.
